topic.title: ZeroGraph Test
topic.body:
ZeroGraph is a ZeroNet merger-zite and library that zites can use to mimic the functionality of OpenGraph.
You can now try out getting an object from ZeroGraph.
Go to this link: [/1DGu17id1u2iQDNzW5oxvJm8A3nWNka735/](/1DGu17id1u2iQDNzW5oxvJm8A3nWNka735/)
Accept the permission, wait for a notification that the merger zite has been added. Then, just above the `Get Object` button, type in this link: `zerograph://12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu/1509922184184` (this is a ZeroGraph Share Link). Then click `Get Object`. The Object information should appear just under the button. Currently only zites and articles are allowed, and not all options are provided for those.

topic.title: ZeroMedium Update 17.12a
topic.body:
### New Features
* You can now use markdown link syntax: `[Link Title](link_address)`
* You can now put space or punctuation after markdown for it to automatically change to visual version. Punctuation includes: . , ! ? ( ) [ ] { }
* You can now add images while editing a story

### Bug Fixes
* Empty responses and stories are *kinda* disallowed (There is still a bug that I'm unsure how to fix)
* The "publish" button is temporarily disabled after clicking it when publishing a response. This prevents people from accidentally clicking it twice, which will post the response twice.
* Images that are uploaded will have the date uploaded appended to the filename. This ensures that there are no collisions with image names.
* For images that are uploaded with non-ascii characters in the filename, the non-ascii characters are removed - this is to prevent a ZeroNet bug with non-latin characters. Spaces are also replaced by underscores and quotes (double and single) are removed.
* The registration will not continue until you select a primary language and enter a username.
* When posting edited story, if title is same as before, no need to add date to end of it
* When interests is empty and you click to follow an interest, do not start the interests string with a comma ','. This prevents there from being an empty interest
http://127.0.0.1:43110/ZeroMedium.bit

3_1Ho48cxWwRFdDChHksp1fhdPvGmpaiZfcH.body: I head that this was fake, but I don't know.

I am fine with this as long as they don't *censor* things. They have never said anything about *censoring* it as far as I know. According to the article I provided below (*which comes directly from Mozilla*), it just looks like they are investing in creating software to fact check things, teaching people about misinformation, and helping fund other misinformation-combatting projects: https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2017/08/08/mozilla-information-trust-initiative-building-movement-fight-misinformation-online/
Furthermore, as far as I can tell, they haven't said they are teaming up with George Soros - this "fact" is coming from sources other than Mozilla themselves.

So, just be careful where you get your information. Like I have said, I don't know if this is true or not, but according to what I have read *directly from Mozilla*, they make no mention of George Soros or of *censoring* things in the future.

> [kmueller](#comment_57_1PvReUtzc5s92BWTUDnxvmVGepNcyA2otB): ADL

I have search for a bit and so far have found no information (including from Mozilla) stating they have partnered with CTR or ADL. To go a step further, Mozilla promotes *Free Choice*, Open Source and Open Internet, Net Neutrality, and Decentralization (as in spreading the market out) - the first of which seems to conflict with your argument about Mozilla.

You are also presupposing that CTR and ADL are liars, slanderers, and communists. Obviously I don't know about the first two, however, I don't think that wanting to stop hate speech and terrorism are related to communism - I may be wrong.

If you are not going to argue using *facts* and *reputable **and direct** sources*, then I am going to be done with this argument. If you are willing to provide these *facts* and *reputable **and direct** sources*, then **I am interested in seeing them.**

> [kmueller](#comment_58_1PvReUtzc5s92BWTUDnxvmVGepNcyA2otB): They are liars slanderers and commies, well marxists actually. And they have no interest in stopping hate speech and terrorist. They just want to shut down what they think is offensive like calling trannies "he" instead of "she" or "xir", this happened recently with the node.js project. [...]

I just read the article you linked. I do agree that you shouldn't have to think about diversity, you should just have to think about who are good programmers, etc. If they end up being diverse, then so be it - but it isn't necessarily racists when there's a person of color or different sexual orientation that you didn't think did a good job with the code, etc. However, I'm not sure that there are or aren't biased people who hire certain people as programmers over others because of their biases. It'd be something that I'd have to research further.

I've also never heard of anything like what was detailed in the article (with the github message about not accepting pull requests from people of color). I just can't believe that that has actually happened. It's sad that people just automatically jump to conclusions with no substantial proof, just imagining a pattern from something they observed. And the thing is, these patterns that people assume out of observations are often wrong - This is precisely why Scientists don't just look at patterns. They conduct multiple experiments and modify hypotheses and theories until they know for sure. I think many people need to work on this more.

9_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof.body:
> [iyogo887vyg87oy8](#comment_23_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof): Yep I think it's a weird thing with Esperanto that its community is bothered about the language itself, as opposed to say how English speakers think of English. IDK I think maybe we could get over this if we were native Esperantists or maybe it's just a unique thing to Esperanto with it being an invention in of itself, much like an iPhone or a car, which people never shut about. I'd like to see non-esperanto things discussed in esperanto so we can use the language instead of obsessing over it lol.

Learning esperanto isn't really a waste of time. Sure, there may not be as many people speaking it as natural languages. But there are other benefits to learning it other than the ability to converse with people who speak it. This is true for any language.

> [rrwtbrsyq8wmackv](#comment_21_1PrxUQFugjmputGP2FzPSw4Wmq6tCd7xV7): If it's true for any language, why not learn a language that also lets you speak to millions?  (When I say "speak" here and in other posts, of course I really mean "communicate with", whether it's out loud or via internet forums or paper mail or whatever.) [...]

There are many benefits to learning *any* language. However, some languages are easier to learn than others. Some languages have much in common with other languages, therefore making those other languages easier to learn if you wanted to learn a third language. Some languages expand your mental idea's/state by being more different semantically, grammatically, and pragmatically than your native language. There are many others. Esperanto hits many of these.

Here's an experiment that was done with Esperanto. One group took french for 4 years. The other group took Esperanto for the first 2-3 years, then took french for the last year(s). Which one knew more French? The second group.

Esperanto lets you get the benefits of speaking another language in less time. After learning Esperanto, it also allows you to learn other languages that would be more useful (because of their higher numbers in speakers) in less time.

However, this is most likely true with languages that are similar to Esperanto: languages that take words from various other languages, that have relatively consistent grammars, and that are easy to remember grammatically, such as Ido and Universal.

I'm also of the opinion that you shouldn't learn a language based on how many people speak it, because chances are you aren't going to be speaking to that many people. The amount of people that speak *any* language isn't a detriment to the language, there's always people to talk to.

Esperanto has a pretty consistent grammar. Languages have many cognitive benefits, yes. Not necessarily with the vocab. They strengthen your brain. They allow you to more easily learn another language. They allow you to learn how to learn a language more effectively, which will improve how you learn your third language. They let you become more exposed to a more variety of cultures, ideas, etc. It improves memory, your native-language skills, etc. It makes you more aware about the specifics of languages (grammar - all languages more or less have very similar things within them, there's also different types of languages, for example inflectional, isolating - each having similar things when looking at morphology and syntax - you should look more into linguistics if you're interested in languages).

But also, there are different Semantics and Pragmatics in different langauges. Different languages categorize or differentiate between things differently. In English there is here, there, and afar - they distinguish between distance (here is closer than there). But in other languages, there may be more words with more differences in distances. Look into Semantics and Pragmatics if you want.

For the study, there were many studies done: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esperanto#Third-language_acquisition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esperanto#Third-language_acquisition). I know that people don't trust Wikipedia, but it does give sources. Here's an exerpt:

> Studies have been conducted in New Zealand,[75] United States,[76][77][78] Germany,[79] Italy[80] and Australia.[81] The results of these studies were favorable and demonstrated that studying Esperanto before another foreign language expedites the acquisition of the other, natural language. This appears to be because learning subsequent foreign languages is easier than learning one's first foreign language, whereas the use of a grammatically simple and culturally flexible auxiliary language like Esperanto lessens the first-language learning hurdle. In one study,[82] a group of European secondary school students studied Esperanto for one year, then French for three years, and ended up with a significantly better command of French than a control group, who studied French for all four years.

> [obiwanzanobi](#comment_55_1LUy9iAxeWsj1DP5L8V17Yb2vo87FucjgD): sounds more like glorified bookmarks.

Kinda. PWAs, which I'm pretty sure is what he is talking about, run in a separate window without any bars at the top and so far, Opera and Chrome work with them. However, Microsoft has already started work on integrating them with their Windows Store, and firefox is also working on implementing them. The also are designed so the web app shows a screen as soon as possible, then download everything else when needed.

However, Instant Apps are completely different. They are a refactoring of Android Apps into modules. Then, the minimum required modules to make the app work and as light as possible are downloaded quickly to make the app appear "instantly". Hence, *Instant* Apps because you don't have to download them, you can try a lightweight version before you do.

> [styromaniac](#comment_129_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): The behavior is identical for shortcuts made with Chromium. [...]

Hold on, I think I know what your saying. Your saying Instant Apps are like PWAs, but for android apps right? I guess that comparison makes sense, but there's pretty big differences under the hood, PWAs being web apps while Instant Apps being modulated Android Apps. I originally thought you were saying that Instant Apps is the "Add to Homescreen" stuff. Then I noticed the "It's identical if ..." part, which suggests analogy.

> [styromaniac](#comment_130_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): I don't really know what PWAs are. What I know is these instant apps show no difference to Chromium shortcuts. [...]

PWAs are the web apps that can be added to your homescreen. They also load progressively, meaning they show a screen instantly, then load things when needed rather than trying to load it all at startup/pageload.

Instant Apps, like I said before, are Android Apps. This means they don't use web technologies, they use Java and the Android Development Kit, etc. They are also contained in APKs, just like normal Android apps. The difference between android apps and instant apps are that instant apps are android apps that have been refactored into modules. This allows google to download only the modules that are needed for the app to run in a *lightweight* mode before you need to install them. You then install them to get the full functionality.

Biggest difference, PWAs use a browser and use web technologies and can be available for all platforms (Microsoft is working to get them into their store, Firefox is working on implementing them, I'm not sure what Apple is going to do with them), Instant Apps don't and are only for Android because they are Android Apps.

> [styromaniac](#comment_131_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): Instant apps I've used behave and look exactly like PWAs.

Yes they behave similarly. But they are not the same. They are **android apps**. PWAs are **Web Apps**. You can also *install* Instant apps, you can't with PWAs. And Instant Apps are only for Android, pwas will be available soon for more platforms than just Android.

ZeroNet zites would work with PWAs, but not with Instant Apps because that would require they become android apps. The only thing we need to make zites into PWAs is service worker support. I actually made an issue on ZeroNet's github about this: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1065

Twitter Lite is a PWA, not an Instant App. The websites that act as apps and allow you to add them to the homescreen are PWAs. 

But yes, we can use PWAs for Zites, but we need service worker support. However, I don't know how it would work when zites are put into iframes.
The thing I said about the modules doesn't apply to Twitter Lite, because the modules are only for Instant Apps, and Twitter Lite is a PWA.

But yes, we can use PWAs for Zites, but we need service worker support. However, I don't know how it would work when zites are put into iframes.

> [styromaniac](#comment_134_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): I believe I've heard from nofish that putting zites into iframes isn't possible.

That's how it works now doesn't it? He puts zites into iframes so he can get the sidebar thing, and so the zite can't do anything outside of the iframe.

If you view the page source, it shows an iframe:

```
<!-- Site Iframe -->
<iframe src='about:blank' id='inner-iframe' sandbox="allow-forms allow-scripts allow-top-navigation allow-popups "></iframe>
```
The problem is the zite inside the iframe needs to talk to a service worker in order to do certain things. Also, I believe service workers are required for PWAs.

In the github issue, I say that if he can't make the zite in the iframe talk to the service worker, he might just be able to add an empty service worker that way we can at the very least add the zite to the homescreen (he'd also need to add settings in the content.json file for the other PWA options).

> [schoolkopykate](#comment_1_15ubGEWWQSXH6Xp1Lg5JcTqMrKVm51BVkg): Just fixed a big ass bug. Video URL router now uses the [certificate user id] + [video date added] in order to link to a video. [...]

That's an interesting way to handle that. What I do with my zites is to have the id's unique, but only for that user (so many users could have something with an id of 1, but we can still refer to it by using both the auth_address and the id) and remove the "PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT" so the id's aren't unique globally and so they don't change per client. Then, the only thing to solve is to have the id's increment, which can be done by storing the next_id in the json file and incrementing that whenever you add a new field to the json file. Then, you just use it as the id when the user posts the next item.

Your way is quicker (and perhaps better) because you don't have to mess with trying to find the next id and storing that (which involves either another table or the keyvalue table).

> [schoolkopykate](#comment_1_15ubGEWWQSXH6Xp1Lg5JcTqMrKVm51BVkg): Just fixed a big ass bug. Video URL router now uses the [certificate user id] + [video date added] in order to link to a video. [...]

btw, if you accept KaffieId, I think you should use auth_address instead of cert_user_id for the routing because multiple people can have the same cert_user_id for KaffieId.

5_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS.body: The problem is the zites have to be able to access the files in order to show them on the zite. Can zites access your computer from outside their own directories?

> [realkittykate](#comment_40_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS): well.. considering how the client is running on your computer, I would assume it should be able to access files outside of zeronet.. i.e. ../../../My_Custom_Big_Files_Folder/data/users/xxxxxxxxxxxxx/this.mp4

Not the client, the zite. Also, the user's content.json needs to be able to know which files are optional so that other clients know this (and so it can get the hash of the files).

> [realkittykate](#comment_40_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS): well.. considering how the client is running on your computer, I would assume it should be able to access files outside of zeronet masterseed folder.. i.e. ../../../My_Custom_Big_Files_Folder/xxxxx/data/users/xxxxxxxxxxxxx/this.mp4

Currently, zites can simply link to the file based on a relative link going into the user's folder. But if we move the files, it will no longer work, which means we need to be able to ask ZeroNet for the directory path of the file, which would mean yet another command. And that's assuming zites are allowed to access anything on the computer, which I don't know if ZeroNet has protections against this.

> [realkittykate](#comment_41_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS): Couldn't this be relative to each individual user's client, though?

Okay, so for example, I have an optional file stored in my user's directory. The zite can access it by going to `data/users/[my auth address]/file.ext`. When someone download's the optional file, the zite will just use this url because it's relative to the zite and it's always located in the same place. But if we start moving files around, we instead have to ask the ZeroNet client where the file was moved to because everyone could move it to different places.

> [krixano](#comment_106_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): Okay, so for example, I have an optional file stored in my user's directory. The zite can access it by going to data/users/[my auth address]/file.ext. When someone download's the optional file, the zite will just use this url because it's relative to the zite and it's always located in the same place. But if we start moving files around, we instead have to ask the ZeroNet client where the file was moved to because everyone could move it to different places.

We also have to be able to write to the correct/desired directory upon upload of a file. And, when the user's content.json file is signed, we have to check that desired directory for files that the user uploaded to their data directory so we can get the file listing and hashes.

> [realkittykate](#comment_42_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS): I suppose there should be a way to set up some automatic symbolic linking system.

I didn't think of that. That would probably be the easiest solution without having to require a lot of changes in ZeroNet client, including potentially breaking changes for zites. You can probably write a plugin for this.

[...]

It doesn't make it more complicated, it's literally the same as it was before big file support as long as you don't use the big files. 

And I also don't know why it would matter whether the big files are in your users directory if their optional. Putting them there allows the sites to actually show/use the files relative to their root, and in the same place.

1512159205_1NpjJ6CEfGa7sDx2VHEEnwrpiy8DX.body:
[Zirch](/zirch.bit) has the most up to date zite list because it is completely automated and updates every hour. [Kaffiene](/kaffiene.bit) and (I believe) [Snifferdog](/snifferdog.bit) are very out of date, and [RVRE](/rvre.bit) I think is less so, but still out of date. [EulerFinder](/13eFkhbXXQcJqd729zRLL9tMxxhz9d4UA6/) is similar to Zirch in that it is one of the most up to date ones and updates every hour, but it has slightly less zites than zirch.

Snifferdog was cloned from Kaffiene (but it might have some differences in what zites it has).

RVRE seems to look the best. Kaffiene, Snifferdog, and EulerFinder look decent/okay. Zirch looks pretty terrible.

RVRE, Kaffiene, and Snifferdog all use hand-written tags I believe, so the search function might be a bit better than Zirch, which doesn't have this, but instead just takes a portion of the index.html file and searches through that (as well as the zite's title *and description*). EulerFinder's searching is very similar to Zirch's.

I don't know very much about Zoogle Zearch since, like EulerFinder, it is pretty new. However, when I originally looked at it, it didn't seem like it had that many zites, but I'm very unsure about this so take this with a grain of salt.

Finally, [ZeroSites](/Sites.ZeroNetwork.bit) has a list of zites, but people have to manually add their zites to it. it also has no search feature. It seems to be pretty up to date for zites that people are adding, but perhaps there are still sites that haven't been added, I don't know. Also, in my opinion the categories could be expanded and the interface is a little annoying, but try it out and see for yourself whether you like it.

People can make their own hubs because you're essentially making your own zite when you do so (but allowing KopyKate to read the data of it). However, other people would need to download the hub to see the posts on it, of course. Imo, hubs in ZeroMe aren't that well done. But, that is not to say that a hub system for KopyKate wouldn't be good, because I think that it could if done right.

> [missesrobot](#comment_5_19WW28sn46rz9h15xf6NCELPdzxZ2YhbyB): So you just basically clone a hub..

Yes. However, you need to move your profile to the hub, too.

> [missesrobot](#comment_6_19WW28sn46rz9h15xf6NCELPdzxZ2YhbyB): Seems like I'd have to turn the current site into a hub (call in King Hub), and then create a central site.I'd have to experiment with clones for now though...Â Should KopyKate become a merger site? That's the question now. They say that it's the only way to allow embedding videos.Â It should also help with splitting large amounts of data, apparently.

KopyKate itself won't become a merger zite. But it will use merger zites to store the data for it.

The reason why merger zites will allow embedding videos into other zites is because zites can ask permission from the user to be able to read the files/information from the merger zite (in fact, this is also how the main zite works too. ZeroMe asks for permission to read from ZeroMe hubs. KopyKate would also have to do this). As far as I know, I don't know if this is possible without merger zites. Although, there is a [CORS plugin](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#corspermission-address) (clearnet), I'm not sure if you could use that instead of (or with) merger zites.

## Concerning ZeroMedium Release Dates
I have decided to do a very small change with how versions are released for [ZeroMedium](/ZeroMedium.bit). The final release date for new versions will *not* change. What *will* change is when versions are released to [ZeroMedium BETA](/15HdD8ZwMLjzQhbDQcF8oRtkbxYxVS7JgU/). Upon the final release of a new version to the official zite, the next version after will also be released to ZeroMedium BETA. *This will give beta versions at least 2 weeks for bug fixes* before being released to the official zite. This also means that I will be working two versions ahead of the official zite.

So what does this mean now? It means that later today (it just turned 12:00am as I am writing this) I will release the next version (17.12b) to ZeroMedium BETA. However, because I did not have much time to get this version out, this version will not have very many changes.

I think one of the main problems is that people aren't posting much stuff. A reason for why this is, which applies to me (but less so I think, since I do post original stuff sometimes) is that developers are too busy with their projects on here. I'm busy with ZeroMedium, ZeroNet Dev Center, ZeroDb, etc. so I can't post much stuff. Ivanq is busy with Git Center and I'm sure some other things. axeltherabbit is busy doing EulerFinder. KopyJane has her own projects (KopyKate/KopyKate Big, and ZeroCat ZeroNet Proxy, as well as other new projects she's working on). And Nofish is of course working on ZeroNet itself (and doing a pretty good job, ZeroNet gets a new revision multiple times a week to fix bugs, etc.). *Along with that, these people probably aren't developing for ZeroNet full-time, either.*

With that said, what might be making ZeroNet appear dead is *not the zite development, but the content of the zites.* Perhaps this could be because we don't have enough people who are *not* working on a zite that would actually have time to post more content.
One other thing that can be paired with this is the exposure ZeroNet is getting and the amount of people joining the network, which both *seem* to be pretty low.

> [james007](#comment_126_1DiRWRFXcVgQQ75cXnAG2pyxxjGo2VaH5): ZeroNet is still more heavily populated than I2P from my view. Certainly not dead.

I'm not saying there's no content, but there isn't very much. I'm definitely not saying ZeroNet is dead, I'm saying it may **appear** dead, and I give *possible* reasons for why it would *appear* this way.

1512976214_18fU1ZPrTrUXVCYG4wDvk6fTB5ok4.body:
> [flappyearz](#comment_104_1QEfmMwKVxgR4rkREbdJYjgUmF3Zy8pwHt): And it's even worse, as I heard, since plenty of people with english as mother tongue haven't learnt grammar, they just try to get along mimicking what others do.

This is very wrong. Everyone learns grammar in school in the US and I'm pretty sure they do in Britain too.

>  I've learnt some grammar most of the US people can't even reproduce.

If you're talking about English grammar, I seriously doubt that. The only thing that other speakers learn that people who speak English as first language don't are the technical words for certain grammatical constructs (perfect, imperfect, infinitive, etc.), however, they still learn some (subject, object, etc). But people who speak English who have learned another language do learn these words as long as they apply to the language they are learning. Btw, it's a requirement for many (I would say majority, but I'm not totally sure about that) colleges to take 2 years of a foreign language.


Finally, it's very well known in Linguistics that speech evolves faster than writing. This is one of the main causes for why spelling doesn't evolve with changes in speech. Another reason is that when new words are brought into English, they are either not changed or barely changed. So, it isn't necessarily completely the fault of the English speakers for why the spelling is messed up. There was already one time where we tried to change the spelling for English to make it more consistent, it was somewhat successful (I believe one of the changes was using er instead of re?). I believe this was when English was standardized. What I'm mainly saying is that written language evolves slower than spoken language, and for this reason, there really isn't a way to completely get around the fact that spelling is going to either remain or become inconsistent with what is spoken. And trying to change it has it's own problems because not everyone will agree on the changes and a lot of people will forget them or just not obey them.

Also, something to note, the English spelling rules are more consistent than what people think.

> [tombombadildo](#comment_8_16AACVBLhoSY2jjGMtP7VKAEbjJUcKgQ1y): Perhaps you can say that everyone is taught grammar in school in the US (though even that is likely an exaggeration), but it is certainly not the case that everyone learns it.

No need to get pedantic, you knew what I meant.

And everyone learns grammar, whether it be direct or indirect or whether it be from listening to other people. If you haven't learned the grammar of a language, you would be misunderstood, you wouldn't be able to speak it, etc. Being taught by example is still being taught. Being taught by listening, speaking, and correction is still being taught.

So, *yes*, everyone *is* **taught** and learns grammar.

That is not to say everyone is taught *well* or that grammar instruction is even needed or effective in schools, those are whole different debates.

1513321800_19WW28sn46rz9h15xf6NCELPdzxZ2.body:
> [missesrobot](#comment_44_19WW28sn46rz9h15xf6NCELPdzxZ2YhbyB): btw - does this work on any zeroframe, or only the zeroframes used in e.g. zeroup, zerome, etc?

Not completely sure what you mean exactly. Do you mean all zeroframe versions? As long as it can access the instance of your ZeroFrame class so it can call a few of the ZeroNet API commands, then it will work. It calls the wrapperPushState, so make sure you have the latest version (you can get that js file [here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroHello/blob/master/template-new/js/ZeroFrame.js), as posted by Nofish). You should look at the [GitHub](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroFrame-Router) I posted, because there is one thing you need to do to get it to work (make sure your zeroframe instance is called `page`, or do `page = zeroframeVariable` as a workaround):

> To navigate to a route, use the Router.navigate('/route') function. *You must also make sure your ZeroFrame instance is called page. (you can get around this by doing something as simple as page = zeroframe;).*
> 
> 
> The order in which you add routes matters. The URL which is added earlier and matches will be the one that is called.
> 
> 
> Note: You must call Router.listenForBack() in the OnRequest() function of your ZeroFrame class in order to detect when the user hits the back button and navigate to the correct route.

Also, this [GitHub page](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroFrame-Router) has much more information than the zite. The zite is a little outdated, but I think there weren't any breaking changes in newer versions released after the zite was last updated, so it still works with the latest version *I believe*.
